site-tagline: A short, research-inspired IQ estimation across five core cognitive domains.
disclaimer: This test is for educational and research purposes only. Scores are approximate and not a clinical or diagnostic assessment.
ui-home-title: Estimate your IQ — free, fast, and anonymous
ui-home-intro: This short cognitive assessment measures reasoning, numerical, verbal, spatial, and memory skills. It follows open psychometric principles inspired by modern intelligence research.
ui-home-tests_count_caption: People have used this free and anonymous assessment.
ui-compare-explainer: Enter two IDs to compare results over time.
ui-compare-notfound: Could not find one or both IDs.
ui-compare-error: Something went wrong. Try again later.
ui-result-lookup_hint: Paste your ID to open your detailed report.
ui-result-disclaimer_iq: Your result reflects performance across five cognitive domains: reasoning, math, verbal, spatial, and memory. It is scored using a normalized model with mean = 100 and standard deviation = 15. Scores are indicative, not diagnostic.
ui-result-iq_explainer_short: Your IQ estimate (mean = 100, SD = 15) is plotted on a normal curve. Most people fall between 85 – 115. Shaded regions indicate standard ability ranges used in research and education.
ui-result-explainer_long: Scores are derived from your accuracy across multiple cognitive domains. Each correct answer contributes to a weighted z-score that is scaled to the population mean (μ = 100, σ = 15). The 95% confidence interval (CI) reflects normal statistical variation based on test length.
ui-result-explanation_method: The scoring model follows widely accepted psychometric conventions similar to those used in standardized ability assessments (e.g., WAIS and Raven matrices). Z-scores across categories are averaged and rescaled to fit the IQ metric.
ui-result-references: References: Condon & Revelle (2014), Wechsler (2008), and other open psychometric frameworks.
ui-result-iq_curve_caption: The curve below shows how your estimated IQ compares to the general population.
category-reasoning-desc: Ability to recognize logical patterns, structures, and relationships between concepts or symbols.
category-math-desc: Skill in analyzing numerical information and solving problems using arithmetic or logic.
category-verbal-desc: Understanding, comparing, and reasoning with written language and verbal analogies.
category-spatial-desc: Ability to mentally rotate, manipulate, and visualize shapes and spatial relationships.
category-memory-desc: Short-term recall, sequence recognition, and concentration on quickly changing information.
report-overview: Your result reflects performance across five key areas of cognition.
report-interpretation: Scores are standardized to a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15. Values between 85–115 are typical. Higher scores indicate stronger reasoning and problem-solving flexibility.
report-categories_explainer: The per-category results highlight your cognitive strengths and development areas.
about-method: This test uses a balanced mix of open-format cognitive tasks modeled after well-established reasoning and aptitude assessments. It estimates general reasoning ability (g) in a transparent and research-oriented way.
about-audience: Suitable for ages 14 and up. Designed for education, personal insight, or preliminary aptitude screening. No personal data is collected — only an anonymous ID is stored for comparison over time.
about-limitations: Results are approximate and can vary with factors such as focus, language, and environment. This tool is educational and not a substitute for a formal psychological evaluation.
iq_explainer-title: How your IQ estimate is calculated
iq_explainer-intro: This assessment uses a research-based method to estimate general cognitive ability (g). It combines multiple domains to produce a standardized IQ-like score for educational and self-reflection purposes.
iq_explainer-method-p1: Each correct answer contributes to your raw accuracy. Scores are weighted across five domains: Reasoning, Math, Verbal, Spatial, and Memory.
iq_explainer-method-p2: Your total is converted into a standardized score using a z-score transformation, then scaled to an IQ-equivalent metric (mean = 100, SD = 15).
iq_explainer-method-p3: A 95% confidence interval (CI) indicates expected variation based on the number of questions and category balance.
iq_explainer-theory-p1: The scoring model follows classical test theory (CTT) principles and psychometric scaling used in validated aptitude and intelligence measures.
iq_explainer-theory-p2: It reflects conventions used in instruments such as the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS-IV) and Raven’s Progressive Matrices, adjusted for open-source testing contexts.
iq_explainer-audience-p1: This test provides a general, research-style IQ estimate that can be used for self-assessment, education, or personal development.
iq_explainer-audience-p2: It does not define intelligence but provides a snapshot of cognitive processing and reasoning efficiency.
iq_explainer-limitations-p1: Results depend on focus, motivation, and familiarity with similar problem types. Re-taking the test may slightly improve scores due to practice effects.
iq_explainer-limitations-p2: This test is anonymous, educational, and non-diagnostic. It should not be used for hiring or clinical decisions.
iq_explainer-summary: In short: this test provides a transparent, research-inspired estimate of general cognitive ability — standardized to the IQ scale (mean 100, SD 15) for intuitive interpretation.
